title: 5 can’t-miss restaurant openings and dining updates in Boston this week
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Capricho Colombian Steakhouse is opening in Brookline, offering fine-dining with wood-grilled prime cuts and live music.
Elephantine Bakery from Portsmouth expands to the Seaport, featuring French technique pastries with Mediterranean influence.
Uncommon Ice Cream debuts in the South End, known for unique flavors like basil with balsamic-roasted strawberry.

title: Do the Bruins have a potential breakout prospect in camp in Dans Locmelis?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Dans Locmelis, a Bruins prospect, impressed during the 2025 IIHF World Championships, scoring four goals and six points in seven games.
Locmelis, a 2022 fourth-round draft pick, signed an entry-level deal with Boston, transitioning successfully from UMass to the AHL.
Providence head coach Ryan Mougenel praises Locmelis' adaptability and courage, highlighting his potential as a future NHL player.

title: Rob Gronkowski: Patriots QB Drake Maye looked ‘timid’ against Raiders
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Rob Gronkowski criticized Patriots QB Drake Maye's performance against the Raiders, describing him as 'timid' during the game.
The Patriots' special-teams and defense also struggled, conceding nine plays of 20 or more yards in a 20-13 loss.
Drake Maye completed 14-of-20 throws for 150 yards and a touchdown but faltered in the second half with an interception.

title: Braintree man dies weeks after being struck by e-bike in Copley Square
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Minh Dang, 64, from Braintree, died after being hit by an e-bike in Copley Square on August 6.
Dang sustained life-threatening injuries after the incident near Huntington Avenue and Dartmouth Street and died weeks later.
The e-bike operator remained at the scene and no charges have been filed, according to Boston police.

title: Watch out for the ‘wicked high’ king tides this week at Boston Harbor
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Boston Harbor will experience 'wicked high' king tides this fall, starting with events on September 11.
King tides occur due to the moon's perigee, making ocean tides two to four feet higher than normal.
The Stone Living Lab will host high tide events at Long Wharf with various dates through December.

title: Stefon Diggs says Drake Maye isn’t a ‘softie’ when it comes to criticism
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Stefon Diggs supports Drake Maye, stating he's tough and can handle criticism for recent performance.
Drake Maye completed 30-of-46 passes for 287 yards in Patriots' 20-13 loss to the Raiders.
Stefon Diggs caught six passes for 57 yards in his Patriots debut after recovering from an ACL injury.

title: Audit: K-12 school department failed to investigate 22 child abuse reports
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: State audit found DESE failed to investigate 22 supported child abuse reports between 2021 and 2023.
DESE and DCF communication breakdown lasted 41 months, affecting handling of child abuse cases involving educators.
Audit also criticized DESE for delays in special education resolutions and inadequate support for LGBTQ initiatives.

title: ‘Nothing short of horrific’: Mass. politicians react to fatal shooting of Charlie Kirk
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Conservative activist Charlie Kirk, 31, was fatally shot at a Utah college political event on September 10, 2025.
Massachusetts politicians, including Gov. Maura Healey, condemned the shooting and denounced political violence on social media.
Authorities questioned and released a person in connection with the shooting; no suspect has been publicly identified.

title: Patriots injury report: Christian Gonzalez not practicing, along with 2 key vets
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Christian Gonzalez remains sidelined with a hamstring injury, absent from Patriots practice since July 28.
Harold Landry and Morgan Moses also missed practice due to foot injuries, impacting defensive and offensive depth.
The Patriots face concerns ahead of their Week 2 game against the Dolphins, struggling with multiple key player injuries.

title: Drake Maye talks starting fast, capitalizing in the red zone, and the throws he wished he had back
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Drake Maye acknowledged rushing some throws, affecting his performance in the Patriots' season-opener loss to the Raiders.
Maye completed 30 of 46 passes for 287 yards, including a red zone touchdown to DeMario Douglas.
Patriots struggled in the red zone, going 1-for-3, highlighting a need for improvement according to Maye.
